metadata.case_name: Quamar Shaffi Tyabji v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad

facts.text: Two cotton mills in Hyderabad State: Azamjahi mills and Osmanshahi mills, public joint stock companies.
Firman-e-Mubarak of 1929 formed Industrial Trust Fund to help industries, managed by Committee of three Government Trustees.

Agreements dated April 12, 1934, and July 27, 1934: Trustees appointed secretaries, treasurers, agents, and selling agents of the two mills, with powers to manage business, appoint employees, and delegate subject to Board approval.
Supplemental agreements dated October 16, 1938: Trustees given power to delegate selling agency powers subject to Board approval.
Till October 1938, Trustees exercised powers through Advisory Board; appellant Quamar Shaffi Tyabji appointed chairman on Rs. 1,500 per month plus commission.

Agreement dated December 6, 1938, between Trustees and appellant: Appellant appointed managing agent of Trustees' business as secretaries, treasurers, agents, and selling agents; full powers delegated subject to general control of Trustees; remuneration Rs. 2,000 per month plus 2% commission on profits subject to profit conditions; separate selling commission; non-assignable; first refusal on transfer.
Appellant conducted business of mills as management and selling agent under 1938 agreement.
Assessed to excess profits tax for chargeable periods 1351F (October 1, 1941 to September 30, 1942): total income Rs. 2,37,451 including Rs. 2,11,230 managing agency allowance and commission.
Assessed to excess profits tax for chargeable periods 1352F (October 1, 1942 to September 30, 1943): total income Rs. 4,90,027 including Rs. 4,45,775 managing agency commission and allowance.
Appellant contended before Excess Profits Tax authorities that he was employee of Industrial Trust Fund, remuneration was salary, not income from business.

Excess Profits Tax authorities negatived contention; High Court of Hyderabad on April 10, 1953, in references under s. 48(3) of Hyderabad Excess Profits Tax Act, answered affirmatively that income was from business.
Appeals by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether in the circumstances of the case, the officers of the Excess-Profits Tax Department were right in treating the income of the assessee or the Industrial Trust Fund as income from business.

petitioner_arguments.text: On true construction of relevant agreements, Industrial Trust Fund was managing and selling agent; Trustees employed appellant on certain terms with certain powers; appellant was employee carrying out duties, not independent business; income was salary, not from business.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Distinction between managing agent and manager under Indian Companies Act, 1913 (citing Inderchand Hari Ram v. CIT)

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant's income was from business of managing agency.

court_reasoning.text: Distinction between agent/servant/independent contractor: principal directs what, master directs how; agent not under direct control/supervision like servant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Relation between Mills and Trustees was principal-agent; delegation to appellant made him agent of principal (Mills), not servant or sub-agent of Trustees (per Indian Contract Act s. 194).

court_reasoning.text: Terms of 1938 agreement: full powers delegated (cl.2), tenure (cl.3), remuneration (cl.4), termination (cl.7), winding up clauses appropriate to business, not master-servant; cl.9 non-assignment does not change to servant relation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant undertook managing agency business under general control of Trustees.

court_reasoning.text: Managing agency is business (citing precedents); appellant had prior business experience.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agreements show agency business, not employment.

holdings.text: High Court correctly answered that income was from business; appellant carried on business of managing agency.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lakshminarayan Ram Gopal and Son Ltd. v. Government of Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Explains distinction between agent, servant, independent contractor; managing agency is business.

precedents_cited.case_name: J.K. Trust, Bombay v. Commissioner of Income-tax Excess Profits Tax, Bombay
Inderchand Hari Ram v. Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between managing agent and manager under Companies Act does not help; issue is construction of agreements.

statutes_cited.name: Hyderabad Excess Profits Tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: References made under this section to High Court.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Position of agent named by sub-delegation.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act, 1913
statutes_cited.relevance: Distinction between managing agent and manager mentioned but not decisive.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court's affirmative answer that assessee's income was from business; appeals dismissed.

key_quotes.text: the difference between the relations of master and servant and of principal and agent lay in this a principal has the right to direct what work the agent has to do but a master has the further right to direct how the work is to be done.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key distinction applied to hold appellant was agent, not servant.

key_quotes.text: managing agency is business see Lakshminarayan Ram Gopal and Son Ltd. v. The Government of Hyderabad and J. K. Trust, Bombay v. The Commissioner of Income-tax
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms that managing agency constitutes business income liable to tax.
